slides.content:
TypeScript Best Practices

Writing clean, scalable, and maintainable code
slides.notes: Welcome the audience to the session. Spend a minute introducing the topic. Mention that this talk will focus on practical tips to improve TypeScript usage and ensure code quality. Ask: 'How many of you are currently using TypeScript in your projects?'

slides.content:
Why TypeScript?

Adding type safety for robust JavaScript development
slides.notes: Spend ~2 minutes here. Highlight why TypeScript has become the go-to choice for modern JavaScript projects. Discuss the importance of type safety in catching errors early and improving collaboration in teams. Transition: 'Now, let’s dive into some best practices for using TypeScript effectively.'

slides.title: Embrace Strict Mode
slides.content:
• Enable strict mode in your tsconfig.json
  • Catch potential bugs early with stricter type checks
  • Recommended flags: noImplicitAny, strictNullChecks, strictPropertyInitialization
slides.notes: Spend 3 minutes. Explain how enabling strict mode helps identify potential issues early in the development cycle. Walk through the key flags like noImplicitAny, strictNullChecks, and strictPropertyInitialization. Ask if anyone has stories about bugs caught by these settings.

slides.title: Prefer Type Aliases over Interfaces
slides.content:
• Type aliases are more versatile
  • Support for unions and intersections
  • Interfaces are still great for OOP-style programming
slides.notes: Spend ~2 minutes. Discuss the flexibility of type aliases in handling complex types like unions and intersections. However, mention that interfaces are still useful for specific use cases, particularly in object-oriented programming scenarios.

slides.title: Use Utility Types
slides.content:
interface User {
  id: number;
  name: string;
  email: string;
}

// Partial: All properties optional
const partialUser: Partial = { name: "John" };

// Readonly: Prevent mutations
const readonlyUser: Readonly = { id: 1, name: "Alice", email: "alice@example.com" };
slides.notes: Spend ~3 minutes. Explain how utility types like Partial and Readonly simplify common scenarios, reducing boilerplate code. Walk through the examples and show how these types make code cleaner and less error-prone.

Emphasize the importance of following best practices to leverage the full power of TypeScript. Encourage the audience to explore these tips in their projects and experiment with adding more type safety to their codebase. Transition: 'Let’s wrap up with the key takeaways.'
